channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/sv52zP2cTs

Potassium-iodide pills that can protect against radiation poisoning are out of stock in much of the U.S., reflecting concerns among some that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could escalate into a nuclear confrontation or accident that could spread radiation https://t.co/BAFAFmRcNl

Some of the world’s biggest banks—including JPMorgan Chase, Standard Chartered and BNP Paribas—worked over the weekend to resolve a crisis in the nickel market that leaves them on the hook for billions of dollars owed by a Chinese metals giant https://t.co/odUbf9b9vU
What is the difference between 5G and 6G? True global ubiquity https://t.co/48XXHFAJjL
William Hurt, the Oscar-winning actor of “Broadcast News,” “Body Heat” and “The Big Chill,” has died. He was 71. https://t.co/8jdrBs7prM
Breaking: Tom Brady said he’s returning to the Buccaneers for his 23rd NFL season, just a little over a month after he retired https://t.co/nxheqavxXS

“Your first reaction is shock. You are stunned. Your mind rejects it.” Residents of an ancient Ukrainian city describe the horror of a Russian bombing that killed more than 47 people. https://t.co/rrCBzBQRHt

Journalist Brent Renaud, an award-winning documentary filmmaker from Arkansas, was shot and killed near the front line of the war in Ukraine, foreign press and local police said Sunday https://t.co/i0z7MuAd2o

From @WSJopinion: The reality of Israel’s dependence on Russia shows again that if the U.S. wants to lead the free world in confronting tyranny, its actions in confronting tyrants must be clear and consistent, writes @NatanSharansky. https://t.co/gB9o5T05Qy
Russia warned Western companies it may arrest executives who criticize the government or seize assets if businesses leave the country, people familiar say https://t.co/IylIuWlKaE

People around the world are using a new website to circumvent the Kremlin’s propaganda machine by sending individual messages about the war in Ukraine to random people in Russia https://t.co/pZRQ4SSCFx

Former President Barack Obama said he is feeling fine after testing positive for Covid-19, and said former first lady Michelle Obama had tested negative: “It’s a reminder to get vaccinated if you haven’t already, even as cases go down.” https://t.co/4UBTueNUF9

U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman suggested Sunday that sanctions appeared to be pulling Russia toward diplomacy: "That pressure is beginning to have some effect. We are seeing some signs of a willingness to have real, serious negotiations." https://t.co/GzwEPECk2c

International efforts to sanction Russia for its invasion of Ukraine have magnified a long-running dilemma for the European Union: Its attempts to wean itself from coal have left it more reliant on Moscow for natural gas. https://t.co/ffOZGFxHfy

The White House privately briefed about 30 social media creators, as administration officials stressed the importance of accurately providing them with accurate information on Ukraine, and countering propaganda efforts from Russia’s government on TikTok https://t.co/bDspKPIVeA

A Chinese company is negotiating with the Taliban to mine one of world’s largest untapped reserves of copper, while Beijing is also in talks to begin work on oil-and-gas reserves in the north of Afghanistan https://t.co/fiAIEIIxFk

Journalist Brent Renaud, an award-winning documentary filmmaker from Arkansas, was shot and killed near the front line of the war in Ukraine, foreign press and local police said Sunday https://t.co/44j7woEA7G

Ukraine’s military said Sunday that a Russian bomber based in the city of Saratov launched the rockets from over the Black Sea. Ukrainian antiaircraft systems destroyed most of them, but eight reached their target on the military base, killing 35 people. https://t.co/a1ewsb4vQC

From @WSJopinion: Biden bemoans today’s skyrocketing gas prices, yet he remains hostage to the green-energy donors whose policies guarantee higher prices. He is enabling Putin’s energy leverage even as he claims the opposite. https://t.co/0dmjkDz4JE
Iran’s top paramilitary force appeared to take responsibility for a missile attack early Sunday that slammed into northern Iraq, sending U.S. troops rushing for shelter https://t.co/u4EkpX3fSq

“Wherever he goes, I go."
Millions are fleeing Ukraine. Others—men signing up to defend their cities, mothers returning after taking children to safety abroad, Ukrainians caring for parents too weak to leave—are going back. https://t.co/5Lo26iW0DZ
Biden wanted to wean the U.S. off oil and lower costs for American families. He’s grappling with how to deliver on those promises amid the crisis in Ukraine. https://t.co/FEVxFRmdo0

Companies from miners to property developers made antitank fortifications. A women’s shoe brand used its luxury Italian leather to make military boots. This is how businesses and civilians are helping Ukraine's war effort. https://t.co/injY1p4ryv

Potassium-iodide pills that can protect against radiation poisoning are out of stock in much of the U.S., reflecting concerns among some that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could escalate into a nuclear confrontation or accident that could spread radiation https://t.co/FpS5hJBUXj

Production of raw materials vital to the semiconductor industry is concentrated in Russia and Ukraine—but after two years of shocks to their supply chain, chip makers were ready for turmoil https://t.co/LbrANGdUna
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine threatens nearly a third of the world’s wheat exports, boosting prices and prompting fears of shortages in countries fed with imported grain https://t.co/f96oUd0IFh
From @WSJopinion: Biden can talk all he wants about his plans to cripple Putin’s economy. He has yet to take the steps that might actually do it, writes @KimStrassel https://t.co/a6Y2u05xyu
The U.S. won't negotiate Russia sanctions to save the Iran nuclear agreement and could pursue an alternative deal excluding Moscow, a U.S. official said https://t.co/63FIEhHBwS
A Russian missile strike killed 35 at a Ukrainian military training base near the Polish border, threatening what has been a vital lifeline for the country https://t.co/e1dHpmdgNp
Covid-19 daily numbers in China are at levels not seen since early 2020, as Omicron tests the country’s zero-tolerance approach https://t.co/RxMOZ5xpfk

People around the world are using a new website to circumvent the Kremlin’s propaganda machine by sending individual messages about the war in Ukraine to random people in Russia https://t.co/78wAhjveyG
As wireless carriers jostle to see who can win the race to deliver 5G services to customers, planning is already well under way for what comes next https://t.co/cAHQDjoS1k

Essay: To show solidarity with Ukraine, many cultural organizations have cut ties with Russia. But ascribing Putin’s brutality to every Russian writer and artist denies the essence of art, writes Suzanne Nossel. https://t.co/uogG61QLLb
Here's what to know about Russian oligarchs and why they're facing heightened scrutiny by Western governments amid the Ukraine crisis https://t.co/IDugkAjJx6

Walt Disney Chief Executive Bob Chapek said the company is pausing all political donations in Florida, following reactions to a bill that the state’s senate passed that would restrict teaching about sexual orientation and gender identity in public schools https://t.co/6qGx9CXUwO
It's important to adjust your workouts when you hit 50. Here are some exercises to help keep you strong and safe into the decades to come. https://t.co/zoAvQX9TOe
A missile strike from Iran landed in the vicinity of an American consulate in Iraq, officials said. The attack comes as the U.S. seeks to revive a nuclear deal with Tehran. https://t.co/9kyBPqaA6y

Video: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has propelled Volodymyr Zelensky onto the world stage. We look at how the former TV star's use of social media brought his wartime messages to a global audience. https://t.co/98zQimcrdg

The Biden administration’s interest in regaining access to Venezuelan oil is facing stiff domestic opposition over concerns it would prop up an autocratic regime and close Russia ally https://t.co/4pc0BLXoao

From @WSJopinion: Putin is beginning to understand the immense difficulty of the war he cavalierly launched in Ukraine, writes @wrmead. Why would he yield power without using every available method to hold on? https://t.co/5wOczSdQ4L
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine risks fueling inflation and sapping growth world-wide, but a handful of nations are in line for an export windfall https://t.co/hsUMNRh1xM

Coca-Cola and McDonald’s are among some of America’s best-known brands that have announced plans to pull back from Russia in response to the country’s invasion of Ukraine #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/UXvzQPa5jf https://t.co/wCVhxXlRBH
The wreck of Ernest Shackleton's ship Endurance, which disappeared under Antarctic sea ice in 1915, has been discovered in a 'brilliant state of preservation' https://t.co/jL28n2MfGc
Airbnb hosts in parts of war-ravaged Ukraine are seeing a surge in online bookings from guests who don’t intend to show up—but do want to show their support https://t.co/WTRWd21Mt1

From @WSJopinion: “Without social media, much of this war would be missed by younger people today. Personal videos and images of this awful war unite us in ways that were once impossible,” writes Elan Koshner. https://t.co/ECChUUCZlw

Saudi Arabia put to death 81 people who had been convicted of crimes including murders, rape, arms smuggling and links to terrorist groups, in the largest known mass execution in the history of the kingdom https://t.co/o68wCgX6ZO
Ukraine has accused Russia of using thermobaric weapons. Here’s what makes them so devastating. https://t.co/EQqoS0cw78
Some surrogate mothers may be stuck in cities under Russian bombardment https://t.co/MY03mzZMkw

A leading rabbi in Portugal who helped a sanctioned Russian billionaire obtain Portuguese citizenship was arrested Thursday as part of a wider corruption investigation, people familiar with the case said https://t.co/OXBNISrGa8

People around the world are using a new website to circumvent the Kremlin’s propaganda machine by sending individual messages about the war in Ukraine to random people in Russia https://t.co/3wXHVytsfk
